author: Special Correspondent
text:
First batch arrives at 11.10 a.m. and the last batch at 3.20 p.m.

All the 3,249 pilgrims, including 694 women and 154 children, returned home safely on Sunday afternoon after celebrating the annual St Antony’s Church festival in the uninhabited Katchatheevu in the Palk Bay.

After Sri Lankan navy handed them over at the International Maritime Boundary Line (IMBL), Indian Coast Guard (ICG) and Coastal Security Group (CSG) personnel escorted the pilgrims to the fishing jetty here. The pilgrims comprised 2,401 men, 694 women, 89 male children and 65 female children.

“All the pilgrims who had gone for the festival in 92 mechanised boats returned safely and no untoward incident was reported,” Superintendent of Police N. Manivannan told The Hindu .

“Everything went off well,” Rev. Fr. L. Sagayaraj, Verkodu Parish Priest and chief coordinator of the pilgrimage, said.

The Jaffna Diocese, which organised the festival and the Consulate General of India in Jaffna made excellent arrangements for the festival, he said.

He said that the Feast Mass, marking the culmination of the two-day festival, which began on Saturday evening, was conducted by Rev. Fr. Justin Gnanaprakasam, Bishop of Jaffna Diocese.

Lankan Navy Commander-in-Chief Ravindra Wijegunaratne was the chief guest, he said.

After the Feast Mass, the Indian pilgrims left the islet in batches. The first batch of 24 pilgrims reached here at 11.10 a.m. and the last batch at 3.20 p.m., police said.

On reaching the fishing jetty here, the pilgrims were allowed to leave after they were cleared by the Customs, Immigration and various other security agencies.
title: Pilgrims return home after festival
